newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan's Formosa to drop China deal if denied permit.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan's Formosa to drop China deal if denied permit.

text.p: Taiwan's Formosa Plastics group promised on Monday to drop an unauthorised US$3 billion power plant in China if Taipei denies the conglomerate a permit allowing it to finance the project.
The statement follows a government inquiry launched earlier on Monday into the controversial project, with officials vowing to take tough measures against any violation.

"If the government ultimately decides not to allow the investment, Formosa group will respect the government's policy and abandon this investment project and turn it over to overseas business groups," Formosa said in a statement.
Formosa Plastics chairman Wang Yung-ching confirmed on Saturday the group had started building the thermal power plant in China's coastal Fujian province in defiance of Taipei.

Taiwan economic affairs minister Wang Chih-kang said he had received assurances from Formosa's Wang Yung-ching that it would withdraw from the project if denied a permit, and said Taiwan had no intention of allowing Formosa to finance the plant.
"We can clearly declare that the government will not allow investment in power plants (in the Chinese mainland)," Wang Chin-kang said on state radio.
Taiwan forbids direct China investments, obliging firms to route even small investments through Hong Kong or other third places after obtaining permits from the economic ministry.
Officials and analysts have said Formosa group could dodge Taiwan's regulations by channelling the funds through its overseas affiliates or holding companies.
But Formosa said on Monday no Formosa unit, affiliate or executive in Taiwan or the United States had put money in the project.
Central Bank governor Sheu Yuan-dong told lawmakers that an initial central bank inquiry showed Formosa had not illegally sent money to China from Taiwan, state media reported.

The announcements from Formosa and the economic ministry capped a day of uncertainty and intense anxiety over the fate of the giant investment, with Taiwan stocks tumbling 1.42 percent -- largely due to a selloff in the plastics sector.
Shares in Formosa's four listed units led the losses.

In June 1996, Formosa said it and local Fujian authorities would jointly build a 3,600-megawatt plant in what easily would have been the biggest Taiwan investment in China and the first in the power sector, which Taipei had banned.
Formosa sought government approval but backed out two months later after President Lee Teng-hui urged local firms to slow their investments in the arch rival Chinese mainland.
Taiwan food giant and top China investor, President Enterprises, said in September 1996 that it had abandoned a US$100 million power station in the central Chinese city of Wuhan.
Communist China has regarded Nationalist-ruled Taiwan as a renegade province since a civil war split them in 1949, vowing to take the island back by force if necessary.
Taiwan says it espouses reunification, but not before Beijing implements democracy.
Taiwan still bans investment in major Chinese strategic projects such as power generation and carmaking as well as banking, insurance and other financial projects.
In 1992, Formosa Plastics withdrew a proposal to build a multi-billion dollar petrochemical complex in China -- again under government pressure.
